keyTakeAways: Dozens of South Korean nationals were repatriated from Cambodia and arrested for alleged involvement in online scam operations, specifically 'pig-butchering' schemes targeting Western victims.
The South Korean government has identified around 1,000 South Korean nationals believed to be working in Cambodia's large-scale scam industry, with many operating under industrial-scale scam centres.

The Prince Group, a Cambodia-based multinational crime network linked to Chinese-Cambodian tycoon Chen Zhi, has been sanctioned by the US and UK for running scam centres and generating tens of millions in daily revenue.
Chen Zhi, who advises Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet and former PM Hun Sen, is wanted for wire fraud and money laundering and faces up to 40 years in prison.
A South Korean college student was found dead in Cambodia in August, with the autopsy confirming severe torture, indicating the extreme risks faced by individuals in scam centres.
South Korea has banned travel to parts of Cambodia to prevent its citizens from joining scam operations, showing domestic policy shifts due to foreign crime risks.
Cambodia’s scam industry has expanded post-pandemic, leveraging the economic downturns and shifting to illicit activities, including online romance scams that target global victims.
The repatriation effort was supported by a bilateral cooperation agreement between South Korea and Cambodia, emphasizing joint action in combating transnational cybercrime.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Dozens of South Korean nationals were repatriated from Cambodia and arrested for alleged involvement in online scam operations, particularly 'pig-butchering' schemes that exploit Western victims through fraudulent investment schemes. The repatriation followed a joint investigation prompted by concerns over citizen safety, with South Korea also announcing a travel ban to Cambodia. The operation is tied to a broader international crackdown on the Prince Group, a Cambodia-based crime network led by Chinese-Cambodian tycoon Chen Zhi, who advises Cambodian leaders and reportedly generated $30 million daily in scam profits. Chen Zhi is wanted for wire fraud and money laundering and faces up to 40 years in prison. The crackdown comes amid growing reports of severe abuse and torture in scam centres, including the death of a South Korean college student in Kampot Province. This incident highlights the scale and dangers of Cambodia’s cybercrime industry, which has expanded since the pandemic and is now linked to political elites and international financial networks.
title: Dozens of South Koreans freed from Cambodia scam centres now home, arrested
